fields.descriptive_line: Theatrical ensemble, gown and two super-tunics, worn by Henry Irving as Synorix in 'The Cup' by Tennyson, 1881, at the Lyceum under Irving's management.
fields.physical_description:
[gown] Cream flannel gown with three bands of metal embroidery at cuffs. Gold button on right cuff, button missing on left. Eight buttons at back to waist, one mismatched. Buttons stamped 'Best Ring Edge'. Triangular panels inserted in back hem. Bodice lined in calico.
[tunic] Cream flannel knee-length super-tunic with square neck and short sleeves. Metallic gold embroidery on centre front, hem and sleeves. Opens at back, fastening with hooks and eyes.
[tunic] Cream wool knee-length tunic, with square neck and short opening at back of neck. Gold metallic braid 'leaf' decoration on sleeves, on front panel, neck and hem, and circles on sleeves.
fields.dimensions:
[gown] Length: 137 cm maximum, Width: 41 cm measured across shoulders, Width: 42 cm measured across chest, Width: 36 cm measured across waist
[tunic] Length: 87 cm maximum, Width: 44 cm measured across shoulders
[tunic] Length: 89 cm maximum, Width: 41 cm measured across shoulders, Width: 49 cm measured across chest
fields.materials_techniques:
[gown] Flannel with metal embroidery
[tunic] Flannel with metallic braid
fields.public_access_description:
Henry Irving (1838-1905) wore this costume as Synorix in Act II of The Cup by Alfred, Lord Tennyson (1809–1892).  The costumes were designed by Edward Godwin (1833–1886), an influential artist of both the Aesthetic and the Arts and Crafts Movements.  The production was praised for its picturesque qualities but the drama, set in Galatia under Roman rule, was criticised for being confusing and lacking substance.  

Irving became a professional actor in 1856, and learned his trade in regional theatres until 1866, when he came to London.  He joined the Lyceum Theatre company under the management of H. L. Bateman in 1871, winning great acclaim that year for his psychologically developed characterisation of the guilt-ridden inn-keeper Mathias in Leopold Lewis’s melodrama The Bells.  He took on the responsibilities of ‘actor-manager’ in 1878 when he assumed the management of the Lyceum, and remained there until 1902, enjoying star status with his leading lady Ellen Terry (1847-1928).   Irving produced a diverse range of old and new plays at the Lyceum, including Shakespeare, historical drama, and literary adaptations.  His tireless work to elevate the status of the theatrical profession was rewarded in 1895 when he became the first actor ever to receive a knighthood for services to the Theatre.

Irving specialised in spectacularly staged productions with large casts of performers. He commissioned designers and composers to create appropriate scenery, costume and incidental music, played by a full orchestra.  Although electric lighting was available from the 1880s, Irving preferred the softer effects of gas, with lime light to focus attention at key points in the play.  Irving toured complete productions outside London, taking the full company, scenery and costumes throughout the United Kingdom and across the United States and Canada.   The development of the railway system made his the first generation able to achieve this level of touring productions.
fields.bibliography: Holmes, Martin. <u>Stage Costumes and Accessories in the London Museum</u>. London : HMSO, 1968. Catalogue entry 87.
